intro: Ranunculus geranioides, commonly known as the creeping buttercup, is a herbaceous perennial native to the western United States. It features a low-growing, spreading habit with bright yellow flowers that have five to seven petals. The plant has finely divided, trifoliate leaves that are often covered in a waxy coating. It thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in meadows, stream banks, and disturbed areas. Its botanical characteristics make it a common weed in agricultural and garden settings.
